summary: This document is a preparation transcript for the trial testimony of David Rodgers, Jeffrey Epstein's former pilot from 1991 to 2019. It details his employment history, responsibilities, descriptions of Epstein's aircraft and properties, flight patterns, interactions with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, and his record-keeping practices, including the instruction to stop logging passenger names in 2007.

persons.name: David Rodgers
persons.context: The deponent, retired pilot employed by Jeffrey Epstein from 1991 to 2019, first as chief pilot and later as captain/flight engineer. He is providing detailed testimony about flight operations, aircraft, passengers, and properties.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as JE, the employer of David Rodgers. Owned multiple aircraft and properties. The document details his travel patterns, residences, and interactions with staff.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as GM, she frequently traveled on Epstein's planes, helped schedule flights, and managed his households. The witness describes her residences and changing relationship with Epstein.

persons.context: Mentioned indirectly as the employer of an aviation manager who connected David Rodgers to Jeffrey Epstein for the pilot job in 1991.

persons.name: John Alessi

connections.description: Rodgers was employed as a pilot for Epstein from July 1991 through 2019.
Maxwell was a close associate who scheduled flights, managed households, and frequently traveled with Epstein. Initially perceived as romantic, later as close friends.
Rodgers received flight instructions from Maxwell and interacted with her during travel and at properties.
Connection implied through shared aviation personnel; an aviation manager working for Wexner facilitated Rodgers's hiring by Epstein.
Indyke was Epstein's attorney and gave instructions to staff (Rodgers) regarding record-keeping.
Indyke, as Epstein's attorney, instructed Rodgers to stop recording passenger names in his logbook in 2007.
Both were staff for Jeffrey Epstein, with Alessi handling ground transportation in Palm Beach.

keyFacts: David Rodgers, Epstein's pilot from 1991-2019, kept detailed personal logbooks of all flights he piloted, including dates, locations, and passenger names.
Rodgers was instructed by Epstein's attorney, Darren Indyke, to stop recording passenger names in his logbook in or about March 2007.
The cockpit door was always closed during flight, and Rodgers stated he could not observe passengers 99% of the time.
Epstein's travel pattern typically involved flying from Palm Beach to New York on Sundays and returning on Thursdays or Fridays.
Ghislaine Maxwell was heavily involved in scheduling flights, especially international ones, and managed Epstein's households.
